did.head: Collection Summary

repository.label: Repository
repository.corpname: Baylor University, The Keston Center for Religion, Politics, and Society

did.abstract: The Bulgaria Subject Files contain a variety of materials on multiple topics, including religious persecution, religious dissidents, human rights activity, state religious policies, atheist propaganda, and discrimination of Turkish ethnic minorities in the country.
did.langmaterial: Bulgarian, English, Russian, German, French, Latvian, Dutch, and Polish

bioghist.head: Biography/Profile
bioghist.p: Keston College, originally founded in 1969 as the Center for the Study of Religion and Communism with the named changed to Keston College in 1974, collected and publicized details about religious persecution behind the Iron Curtain, becoming “the voice of the voiceless.” After the collapse of communism in the 1990s, Keston College moved to Oxford and downsized due to decreased funding. The name eventually changed to Keston Institute. In 2007, the Institute transferred the Keston Archive and Library to the newly created Keston Center for Religion, Politics, and Society at Baylor University.

Keston collected, verified, translated, and disseminated information received from believers in the Soviet Union, Poland, Romania, Czechoslovakia, Hungary, Yugoslavia, Bulgaria and other communist countries. The Keston Archive and Library housed numerous letters, petitions, reports and underground publications (Samizdat) from believers of various denominations along with officially published books and periodicals.

From the beginning of the post-World War II period until approximately 2007, Keston obtained materials documenting the religious and political climate and persecution in Bulgaria, a country which suffered under a communist dictatorship from 1948 to 1991.

Although Bulgaria declared neutrality at the outbreak of the war, by 1941 Tsar Boris III had entered the war on the side of the German powers. The Tsar did not declare war on the Soviet Union, as he feared division within the country. Bulgaria remained largely untouched by World War II, sending no troops to assist at the front. Tsar Boris III suffered a heart attack in 1943 and did not survive to see the war’s end. A long line of temporary leaders succeeded him until the consolidation of communist power in 1948. Bulgaria remained under Soviet occupation from 1944 to 1947, which aided the communist rise and consolidation of power.

p.emph: The Rise of the Communist Party in Bulgaria

bioghist.p: Public opinion against Bulgaria’s role in World War II allowed the rising communist party to take advantage of the situation by executing and imprisoning large numbers of political enemies by creating a “people’s court” in which thousands stood trial for their role in the war. The purge effectively silenced the majority of anti-communist sentiment. Remaining communist opposition was quelled when Western democracies determined that democratization of Bulgaria was a low priority, essentially allowing Stalinism to be established in the country.

The communist party formally consolidated their power in the 1945 election. In 1946, Bulgaria was declared a republic, forcing Tsar Simeon II and his family into exile. One week after the election of a communist majority Grand National Assembly, both the United States and Great Britain formally recognized the new communist regime. The Grand National Assembly enacted the Dimitrov Constitution on December 4, 1947, which was modeled after the constitution of the Soviet Union and established a formal communist structure in Bulgaria.

The Bulgarian government saw a rapid succession of leaders in the early years of the regime until Vulko Chervenkov took power and implemented Stalinism, including rapid industrialization, forced collectivization of agriculture, heavy reliance on the police and security apparatus, and isolation from countries outside the Soviet bloc. After Stalin’s death in 1953, Chervenkov yielded power to an up and coming member of the communist party, Todor Zhivkov. In 1956, Zhivkov began the open de-Stalinization of Bulgaria, which included the release of thousands of political prisoners and the moderation of economic policies in order to raise the standard of living.

Todor Zhivkov became prime minister in 1962 and remained in power until 1989. During his rule, Bulgaria and the Soviet Union created extremely close political and economic ties. Zhivkov’s policies stressed the importance of science and technology, bringing the Bulgarian economic sector out of agriculture and into industry and service sectors. “Bulgarization” was a major movement during Zhivkov’s rule and encouraged larger families and the assimilation of Turkish minorities. Assimilation included discontinuing Turkish publications and forcing ethnic Bulgarian Turks to adopt Bulgarian names. In 1989, the Turkish government allowed the Bulgarian border to reopen so that Turkey could accept Turkish refugees fleeing persecution. More than 300,000 ethnic Turks fled or were forced out of Bulgaria and into Turkey.

Mikhail Gorbachev’s reforms of glasnost and perestroika in the late 1980’s greatly impacted Bulgaria. Bulgarians began to push for further economic openness and government reform. An increase in Bulgarian dissidents, a declining economic situation, and internal party rivalries led Zhivkov’s colleagues to force his resignation on November 10, 1989. He was later tried, sentenced, and imprisoned for embezzlement. Bulgaria held free elections in 1990, and the communist party barely earned a majority. However, their majority was not large enough to govern alone, and the party supported a non-party member for election as Prime Minister. In 1991, the Grand National Assembly adopted a new constitution that established Bulgaria as a parliamentary republic, effectively ending complete communist rule.

Exarch Stefan, head of the Bulgarian Orthodox Church, resisted government efforts to control church activities. He left office in 1948 and retired to a monastery under mysterious circumstances. His replacement allowed complete governmental control over religious activities, including legislation passed in 1949 that allowed state supervision for all religious orders. After the implementation of the legislation, 15 pastors from evangelical Protestant churches were arrested, tried, and executed for espionage and other alleged crimes. Soon after, a number of Bulgarian Catholic clergy were tried for spying for the Vatican and for disseminating anticommunist propaganda. Among the executed was Bishop Evgeny Bosilkov, beatified by the Vatican in 1998.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: Bulgaria subject files consist of newspaper clippings, bibliographic references, handwritten notes, correspondence, research papers, manuscripts, church and secular publications, reports on issues of religion and atheism and religious dissidents in Bulgaria, and Keston News Service publications.

The materials cover a period from 1946 to 2006 with the bulk from 1968 to 1989. The most notable topics include, but are not limited to, discrimination of Turkish ethnic minorities, Bulgarian Communist Party activity, and traditional Bulgarian culture within the communist state.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: The Keston Center received most of the Bulgaria materials in files organized by specific categories and denominations. This original filing system has been preserved. The Bulgaria materials received by the Keston Center in no particular order are arranged thematically and chronologically.
The Bulgaria Subject Files are arranged in two series: I. General and II. Denominational materials. The Denominational materials are in progress.

accessrestrict.head: Access Restrictions
accessrestrict.p: All requests for copying of materials must be submitted to the Keston Center for Religion, Politics, and Society in writing. Please use the Request Form for Copying Materials sheet. Unpublished materials authored or otherwise produced by the creator (s) of this collection are in the public domain. There are no restrictions on use. Copyright status for other collection materials is unknown. Transmission or reproduction of materials protected by U.S. Copyright Law (Title 17, U.S.C.) beyond that allowed by fair use requires the written permission of the copyright owners. Works not in the public domain cannot be commercially exploited without permission of the copyright owners. Responsibility for any use rests exclusively with the user.

userestrict.head: Use/Re-use Restrictions
userestrict.p: The collection is open for research.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Bulgaria Subject Files, Box #, Folder #, Keston Center for Religion, Politics, and Society, Baylor University.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: Archivist''s Notes: The Keston Center is grateful to Victoria Royal and Rachel Jacob for their assistance in processing the Bulgaria subject files and in preparing the finding aid.

bioghist.head: Biography/Profile
bioghist.p: General Bulgaria subject files contain materials on religious persecution, human rights activity, state religious policies, atheist propaganda, communist ideology, publications, reports, Bulgarian culture, society, and dissident activity.
